column1: Jonesboro is a city located on Crowley's Ridge in the northeastern corner of the U.S. State of Arkansas.  Jonesboro is one of two county seats of Craighead County.  According to the 2010 Census
column2: the city had a population of 67
column3: 263 and is the fifth-largest city in Arkansas.  In 2010

column4: and the Quapaw. The name of the state of Arkansas comes from the Quapaw language. French and Spanish traders and trappers had relations with these groups.

column1: After the United States acquired this territory in the Louisiana Purchase of 1803
column2: American settlers eventually made their way to the area where Jonesboro is located. They began exploring
column3: hunting
column4: trapping
column5: and trading with the local Indian tribes. A permanent settlement of Jonesboro was set up shortly after 1815.

column2: land was taken from nearby Greene
column3: Mississippi
column4: and Poinsett counties and was used to form Craighead County. Jonesboro was designated as the original county seat. As the population increased in the west of the county
column5: Lake City was named as the second seat. Jonesboro had 150 residents in 1859. It was named after State Senator William A. Jones in recognition of his support for the formation of Craighead County. Originally spelled Jonesborough
column6: the city name was later shortened to its present-day spelling.

column2: the city tried to develop its court system and downtown infrastructure. Shortly after the city was named county seat
column3: the highest point in Jonesboro was identified and a courthouse was planned for construction. This was delayed for several years
column4: for the locals did not want to ruin their deer hunting. The first courthouse was finally completed but was destroyed by a fire in 1869. A store across from this site was rented and used as a courthouse. It was destroyed in an 1876 fire. Another building was constructed on the same site
column5: but it fell to a fire in 1878
column6: a major one that destroyed most of downtown Jonesboro. Soon afterward
column7: another courthouse was constructed; it was replaced by the present courthouse in 1934.

column2: known as the Cotton Belt Railroad was constructed through Jonesboro
column3: with its tracks passing just north of the center of the city. During the first train's journey
column4: it became stuck and supplies had to be carried into town. It connected St. Louis to points in Arkansas and Texas. Other major railways began to construct tracks to and from Jonesboro
column5: including the St. Louis–San Francisco Railway and Missouri Pacific Railroad. Some of the rail companies still own and use the tracks that run through Jonesboro.

column1: The city set up the Jonesboro School District in 1899. In 1900

column3: the first department store in the city
column4: was opened in 1900. Woodland College and two schools within the Jonesboro School District were opened in 1904. Arkansas State College (now Arkansas State University) was established in 1909
column5: a year in which the first horseless carriages were driven in the city. There is a recording on a Sanborn Fire Insurance Map dating back to March 1897 of a Presbyterian Church existing at the corner of Church St. and Monroe
column6: and a Christian church located at the corner of Union and Huntington Ave. Other early churches of the city were started in the 1910s. First Baptist Church was founded in 1911

column3: Governor Harvey Parnell authorized the Arkansas National Guard to be deployed in Jonesboro to quell the Church War
column4: a clash between the followers of Joe Jeffers and Dow H. Heard
column5: the pastor of the First Baptist Church of Jonesboro. Jeffers' supporters also attacked the mayor and police chief
column6: resulting in front-page coverage of the incident in The New York Times.

column1: The Jonesboro Lynching of 1881 took place at midnight on March 12. The Decatur Daily Republican reported that four black men—Green Harris (sometimes referred to as Hawes)
column3: John Woods (sometimes referred to as Jud Woods)
column4: and Burt Hoskins (sometimes referred to as Haskins)—had been arrested and tried before magistrates Jackson and Akers at New Haven Church
column5: eight miles north of Jonesboro. The hearing
column6: which found that the men were guilty
column7: was attended by several hundred people. According to this and several other reports
column8: the accused made a complete confession. The magistrates bound them over to the grand jury
column9: and they were ordered taken to the jail in Jonesboro. The hour being late
column11: it was decided to hold them overnight in the church under a strong guard. The large crowd gradually dispersed

column2: between 200 and 300 masked men surrounded the church
column3: overpowered the guards
column4: and broke in the doors and windows. They seized the accused
column5: dragged them to a tree about 200 yards away
column8: "leaving the bodies of their victims dangling in the air and presenting a horrible spectacle in the moonlight." According to the Republican
column9: "The crime and punishment form one of the blackest pages in the annals of the state."Encyclopedia of Arkansas

column5: and injured 10 persons.In the 2007–2008 school year the Jonesboro Public School District elementary schools were reclassified as magnet schools.
